title: Granit Xhaka needed Arsenal fans' support but suffered worst experience for a footballer
text:

Granit Xhaka should not have reacted by cupping an ear and telling Arsenal fans where to stick it when he was booed off on Sunday.

But the lad is only human and I dare bet the majority of us would have said and done something similar if we’d found ourselves in his position.

Being booed by your own fans has to be one of the worst experiences for a footballer.

And for Arsenal supporters to turn on him the way they did, whether it was for his performance or because he wasn’t getting off the field as quickly as they’d have liked, was bad form of the highest order.

(Image: Visionhaus)

(Image: REUTERS)

It’s not like they haven’t got previous for it, because they reduced Emmanuel Eboue to tears in 2008.

But they haven’t learned their lesson and I just can’t abide by any of that because surely the whole idea of being a supporter is that you support your team and your players through thick and thin.

If a player is having a stinker you should clap him to try to get him going, and if that doesn’t have the desired effect and the manager hooks him, you should clap him again on the way off.

That gives players the belief to go and fix things on the training ground, but booing them will do the exact opposite and make them not want to go into work.

(Image: Shaun Botterill/Getty)

(Image: Reuters)

Most of the blame for all of this lies with Unai Emery, because it was his decision to make Xhaka the captain when everyone else could see it was a ticking time-bomb.

He’s one of those who always risks getting sent off or banned through the totting-up process and fans quickly get frustrated with any player they deem a liability.

What seems to have happened at Arsenal is that all the frustrations from the last few years of Arsene Wenger and the first year-and-a-half of Emery have swirled around together and finally been spat out in pure spite.

Xhaka has taken the brunt of it and that’s unfair because this wasn’t a case of a player not trying, just a case of a player who isn’t very good, and that isn’t a crime.

(Image: WILL OLIVER/EPA-EFE/REX)

Emery could have given the armband to any of his players because there isn’t a standout candidate like a Tony Adams or Patrick Vieira in the group.

But it went to Xhaka and it was always going to come back to bite him.

It looks like 30,000 to 40,000 fans who long for what they used to see at Highbury are pouring out their frustrations and being joined by modern fans who hear the boos and think, ‘I might as well get involved as well’.

And that’s the worst part of the unwritten contract that exists between players and fans.

(Image: PA)

For Xhaka, there’s hardly any coming back from this because if he does well then people will say, ‘We were right to boo him’.

And if he crumbles, as would happen to most players, then he’s done for anyway.

What he needed was the same thing all players need — the support of his fans.

But what he got was the very opposite.
description: Granit Xhaka should never have been made Arsenal captain and there is hardly coming back from Sunday's incident
